lead_paragraph: In a decision giving local school districts control over bilingual education, the California Board of Education today rescinded a policy requiring that students with limited English skills be taught in their native language. The surprise move came in response to a petition filed with the board by the conservative Pacific Legal Foundation on Feb. 17. The petition argued that because the state's bilingual education law expired in 1987, the board was acting beyond the scope of law when it required districts to obtain permission for English-only programs.
